title: WhatsApp Wins Lawsuit Against Pegasus Maker As US Judge Finds NSO Guilty In Spyware Case - News18
summary:
WhatsApp Wins Lawsuit Against NSO Group in Spyware Case

Date: December 21, 2024

Source: News18

WhatsApp has achieved a legal victory against the NSO Group, which is known for developing the Pegasus spyware. A US judge ruled that NSO Group violated US hacking laws and WhatsApp's terms of service.

  • WhatsApp filed the lawsuit accusing NSO of hacking 1,400 individuals in May 2019.
  • The judge ruled in favor of WhatsApp, stating that NSO's actions were illegal.
  • A jury trial is scheduled for March 2025 to determine the damages owed to WhatsApp.
  • WhatsApp emphasized the need for accountability for spyware companies targeting vulnerable groups.
  • NSO was found to be non-cooperative during the case and faced sanctions for not providing necessary information.
  • The US government blacklisted NSO in 2021, prohibiting its agencies from utilizing its products.
NSO must be held accountable for targeting journalists, human rights activists, and civil society groups.

This ruling marks a significant win for WhatsApp in its ongoing battle against spyware and underscores the rising scrutiny on tech companies involved in such practices.
newTitle: WhatsApp Wins Lawsuit Against NSO Group in Spyware Case

Key Points

  • Experts recommend investing in IRFC for long-term returns of 6-12 months or more.
  • The railway sector is undergoing transformation focused on infrastructure development and enhancing passenger experience.
  • IRFC shares have delivered positive returns of 52% in BSE data, with impressive multibagger returns over 365% and 570% in the last two and three years, respectively.
  • The company boasts a dividend yield of 0.98% and a market valuation of Rs 1,99,752.11 crore.
Gaurang Shah, market expert: "An IRFC investor should invest only if he/she has long-term views... you will be rewarded very good."

Overall, investing in IRFC is perceived as a long-term strategy given the current market corrections.

summary:
Oil sheds 3% in 5 days on US Fed rate cut outlook, weak Chinese demand; Brent slips below $73/bbl

Publication Date: Not specified
Source: Live Mint

International crude oil prices faced a decline due to weak demand from China and a less aggressive stance from the US Federal Reserve on interest rate cuts.

  • Brent crude futures settled at $72.94 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude stood at $69.46.
  • Market concerns over US Federal Reserve's support for oil demand amidst rate cut outlook.
  • China's crude imports are predicted to peak by 2025, leading to weak demand projections.
  • OPEC has lowered its growth forecast for global oil demand for five consecutive months.
  • JPMorgan forecasts a shift from oil market balance to surplus by 2025.
  • Discussions are ongoing among G7 nations about tightening the price cap on Russian crude.
  • Industry experts predict ongoing volatility in crude oil prices.
“Record strength in the dollar index after FOMC meeting outcomes and the US Fed hawkish guidance for 2025 rate cuts could restrict crude oil gains.” - Rahul Kalantri, VP of Commodities, Mehta Equities Ltd

The recent changes in oil prices reflect broader economic factors, including interest rates and international trade situations that continue to keep the market on edge.

title: Vedanta demerger plan revised - Anil Agarwal-led company says 'shareholders will…’ - ET Now
summary:
Vedanta Demerger Plan Revised - Anil Agarwal-led Company Says 'Shareholders Will…’

Updated: December 21, 2024, 15:04 IST, Source: ET Now

Billionaire Anil Agarwal-led mining major Vedanta Limited has announced a revision in its proposed and anticipated demerger plan, initially announced in September last year, stating that it will now retain its base metals undertaking within the parent firm.

  • The initial plan involved demerging 6 entities that would be listed on the bourses.
  • Recent deliberations with stakeholders led to the decision to keep the base metals unit within the parent company.
  • Lenders believe this scheme favors value unlocking and optimal debt allocation.
  • The demerger of the base metals undertaking may be considered in the future as the business evolves.
  • Shareholders will retain their value in the base metals business and receive equivalent shares in the resulting companies.
  • The demerger process is expected to be concluded in the first quarter of next year.
“We will have a very good dividend policy. Share price will do very well according to me.” - Anil Agarwal, Chairman of Vedanta

The revision of the demerger plan signifies a strategic decision by Vedanta, aiming to enhance shareholder value while ensuring better management of its assets.
newTitle: Vedanta Demerger Plan Revised by Anil Agarwal-led Company

title: IBC | Moratorium Does Not Extinguish Claim : Supreme Court - Live Law - Indian Legal News
summary:
Supreme Court Ruling: Moratorium Does Not Extinguish Claims Under IBC

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Live Law

The Supreme Court has clarified that a moratorium declared under Section 14 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016 does not extinguish claims, allowing creditors to make claims even during a moratorium.

  • The moratorium bars legal actions against corporate debtors but does not erase their liabilities.
  • The ruling was made by Justice Abhay S Oka and Justice Pankaj Mithal.
  • The Court noted that creditors still have provisions to file claims during a moratorium.
“If the argument that the claims of all the creditors of the Corporate Debtor are extinguished once the moratorium comes into force is accepted, no creditor would be able to file a claim.”

This judgment sets a precedent for how creditors can proceed with claiming dues during insolvency proceedings.
newTitle: Supreme Court Ruling: Moratorium Does Not Extinguish Claims Under IBC

title: New Rs 15 Lakh SUV Better Than Mahindra XUV 3XO? - MotorOctane
In Suit For Declaration Of Title With Further Relief Of Possession, Limitation Period Of 12 Years... - Live Law - Indian Legal News
summary:
Supreme Court Ruling Clarifies Limitation Period for Declaration of Title

Publication Date: 2024

Source: LiveLaw

The Supreme Court of India has clarified that there is no limitation period for suits requesting a declaration of title, as long as the right to the property continues. However, the limitation for possession claims is governed by the applicable Article of the Limitation Act.

  • The Court emphasized that a declaration of title does not expire as long as the right to the property exists.
  • When seeking possession alongside a declaration, the case is governed by Articles that pertain to possession.
  • The ruling reaffirmed the importance of proving adverse possession by the defendant for a limitation defense to hold.
  • The specific case involved an appeal against a Karnataka High Court decision allowing a plaintiff to amend a suit to include a claim for possession.
  • The Court ruled in favor of the plaintiff, reaffirming their right to seek possession based on title.
“A suit for a declaration of title to immovable property would not be barred so long as the right to such a property continues and subsists.” – Supreme Court

In conclusion, this ruling emphasizes that plaintiffs can seek relief based on established title without facing limitation issues unless defendants can prove adverse possession.
newTitle: Supreme Court Ruling Clarifies Limitation Period for Declaration of Title

title: Vedanta, Mazagon Dock among 5 stocks with dividends, bonuses, & splits this week! Do you own any? - The Economic Times
In significant ruling, WhatsApp wins case against Pegasus spyware-maker - The Indian Express
summary:
WhatsApp Wins Case Against NSO Group for Pegasus Spyware

Publication Date: December 21, 2024 | Source: The Indian Express

In a significant ruling, a U.S. District Court held NSO Group liable for targeting 1,400 WhatsApp users via the Pegasus spyware, used by government clients to infect devices of activists and journalists.

  • NSO Group was found to have violated the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA) and California's Computer Data Access and Fraud Act (CDAFA).
  • The ruling came five years after WhatsApp filed the lawsuit against NSO Group in October 2019.
  • The ruling acknowledges WhatsApp's claims regarding NSO Group's violation of its terms of service.
  • WhatsApp's head, Will Cathcart, described the ruling as a huge win for privacy, emphasizing accountability for spyware companies.
  • This marks the first time a court has held NSO Group accountable for its spyware activities.
  • WhatsApp alleged NSO Group reverse-engineered its source code to develop hacking vectors for their government clients.
“The ruling is a huge win for privacy... illegal spying will not be tolerated.” – Will Cathcart

The case now moves to determine damages, with the deliberations set to begin in March 2025.
newTitle: WhatsApp Wins Case Against NSO Group for Pegasus Spyware
